tutorial.title: Access multiple HTML Elements
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to code dynamic webpages.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
So far we've only looked at ways of accessing one element at a time with methods like getElementById() or querySelector().

Make sure to pick querySelector.

lessons.title: Collections
lessons.interactiveContent:
But what if we want to access more than one element at a time? For example, what if we wanted to count items in a list?

Press the button to count how many li items there are.

lessons.title: GetElementsByTagName
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can get a collection of elements of the same tag type with getElementsByTagName().

Complete the code and press the button to see the collection length.

Make sure to pick get followed by Elements and then By, Tag, Name.

lessons.title: Like arrays
lessons.interactiveContent:
Collections are similar to arrays. They work with indices that start from 0. Display the first element's HTML content.

Make sure to pick el followed by [ and then 0, ].

lessons.title: Length
lessons.interactiveContent:
Just like arrays, we can also access the length property of the collection.

Make sure to pick el, followed by ., and finally length.

lessons.title: ClassName
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to return a collection that contains specific elements of a class, we can use the getElementsByClassName() method instead.

Press the button to display how many elements of class urgent there are.

Make sure to pick getElementsByClassName.

lessons.title: ClassName Index
lessons.interactiveContent:
Since getElementsByClassName() also returns a collection, we can then access each element through the index. Display the first urgent task.

Make sure to pick el[0].

lessons.title: More than one
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access multiple elements that have more than one class, we just add the classes with a space in between. Code urgent important.

Make sure to pick urgent, followed by important.

lessons.title: Question: Collections
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does getElementsByTagName() return?

A collection of elements that have the same tagAn array of elements that have the same tag

A collection of elements that have the same tag.

lessons.title: Question: GetElementsByTagName
lessons.interactiveContent:
At what index does a collection start?

0, like an array1

0, like an array.

lessons.title: Question: Like arrays
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does getElementsByClassName() return?

A collection of elements that have the same class selectorA collection of elements that have the same class or tag selector

A collection of elements that have the same class selector.

lessons.title: Question: Length
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display in the paragraph?

5Tony

Make sure to pick 5.

lessons.title: Question: Length II
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display in the paragraph?

1Michael

Make sure to pick 1.

lessons.title: Question: ClassName
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code do?

It changes the first heading of the class adventureIt changes the first heading on the page

It changes the first heading of the class adventure.

lessons.title: Example: GetElementsByTagName
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code el.length to display the number of h4 headings on the page.

Make sure to type el.length.

lessons.title: Example: Like arrays
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the fourth element's HTML content.

Make sure to pick 3.

lessons.title: Example: ClassName
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the correct method.

Make sure to pick getElementsByClassName.

lessons.title: Example: ClassName Index
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the second urgent task.

Make sure to type el[1].

lessons.title: Example: More than one
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the correct second class to display buy milk.

Make sure to pick important.

lessons.title: Example: More than one II
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the correct class to change the last h4 element.

Make sure to type comedy.

lessons.title: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
We know how to retrieve multiple elements if they had the same tag or class name. Like all the h3 here.

Make sure to pick "h3".

lessons.title: Second element
lessons.interactiveContent:
There's also another powerful way of getting array-like lists of elements, and that's with the querySelectorAll() method.

Make sure to pick querySelectorAll.

lessons.title: Classes
lessons.interactiveContent:
The great thing about querySelectorAll() is that it works for both tag and class names.

Make sure to pick ., followed by urgent.

lessons.title: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use querySelectorAll to look for specific elements, like a h3 element of class news.

Make sure to pick h3, followed by ., and finally news.

lessons.title: Advanced searches
lessons.interactiveContent:
The querySelectorAll() lets us do more advanced searches, like accessing elements of two different classes at the same time.

In this example, we're looking for elements of either class movie or tech.

Make sure to pick ".movie, .tech".

lessons.title: Advanced searches II
lessons.interactiveContent:
To get elements that belong to two different classes, we just add one class after the other separated by a comma.

Code .movie, .tech to see that two heading elements are stored in the variable.

Make sure to pick .movie, followed by ,, and finally .tech.

lessons.title: Advanced searches III
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can even combine selectors like classes, tags, or IDs. Add the button tag name to retrieve it also and display its text in the paragraph.

Make sure to type button.

lessons.title: Question: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is querySelectorAll() useful?

Because it allows us to select all elements and not just oneIt's not, it's the same as querySelector()

Because it allows us to select all elements and not just one.

lessons.title: Question: Classes
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we use querySelectorAll() when looking for elements of a specific class?

We need to add a period before the classWe just write the class inside the parentheses

We need to add a period before the class.

lessons.title: Question: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

It should be querySelectorAll()It should be h3.news in parentheses

It should be querySelectorAll().

lessons.title: Question: Advanced searches
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code do?

Returns number of elements of either class .movie or .techReturns number of elements that have both class .movie and .tech set

Returns number of elements of either class .movie or .tech.

lessons.title: Question: Advanced searches II
lessons.interactiveContent:
What types of selectors can we combine inside querySelectorAll()?

All types of selectors as long as they're separated by a commaOnly class and tag names

All types of selectors as long as they're separated by a comma.

lessons.title: Question: Advanced searches III
lessons.interactiveContent:
What gets displayed in the paragraph?

42

Make sure to pick 4.

lessons.title: Example: Second element
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code querySelectorAll.

Make sure to type querySelectorAll.

lessons.title: Example: Classes
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code .urgent to retrieve the number of elements with class urgent.

Make sure to type .urgent.

lessons.title: Example: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
To retrieve the elements that have both the class sports and news, code .sports.news.

Make sure to pick . followed by sports and then ., news.

lessons.title: Example: Advanced searches
lessons.interactiveContent:
To retrieve the number of elements that have either the class sports or tech, code .sports, .tech.

Make sure to pick . followed by sports and then ,, ., tech.

lessons.title: Example: Advanced searches III
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the img tag name to retrieve it as the last element.

Make sure to type img.
